text: wow what an introduction what a room
that's it's good to be home here I will
say it is a real honor to be back on
campus and to mark this important
important moment in the history of
Harvard Business School and to be part
of this summit I just want to take a
moment to thank all of the people who
work so hard to make this possible it is
a grand event
you know I know I speak for everyone in
this room where I said when I say that
this is an institution that we cherish
the memories the experiences and the
skills that we gained on this campus
help guide us both in our personal and
our professional lives this is where we
learned how to problem-solve how to
build teams and how to lead this is a
unique institution with a proud
tradition and a strong future and I want
to thank president Faust she's an
inspiration to all women and to all men
and our own leader and inspiration de
nuria thank you both thank you both for
making sure that Harvard Business School
continues to produce the leaders and the
scholarship that will define our
nation's economic future the mission of
the Harvard Business School we all know
it is to educate leaders who make a
difference in the world and each of us
here today wants to make sure that more
of those leaders are women
now this conference comes at a perfect
time as we find ourselves engaged in an
important dialogue about balancing
family and work and about pursue
ensuring our place in positions of power
and if I have one underlying message
today it's that we belong we belong as
the CEOs of major corporations and in
the highest levels of government we
belong at the helm of universities and
financial institutions we belong because
we are uniquely suited to excel in those
positions to manage global organizations
and to provide leadership and strategic
counsel at the highest levels of
Corporate America and government now the
opportunity to serve as part of the
president of President Obama's cabinet
and as a member of his economic team has
really brought that home to me let me
tell you about some of the voices that
are around the table when we're
developing economic policy there are
women like Ursula burns of Xerox that
drew mentioned this morning and our own
Sheryl Sandberg as well as penny
Pritzker and as you know Cheryl and
Penny are going to be both speaking
later in this conference these women
advise the president in the cabinet on
job creation and export growth
strategies and I'll never forget my
first cabinet meeting I'll never forget
it walking in secretary Hillary Clinton
Secretary Kathleen Sebelius Janet
Napolitano peloton oh she's the
secretary of homeland security and you
can be more secure because she's there
Ambassador Susan Rice Labor Secretary
Hilda Solis you know these are powerful
women working to solve some of the most
pressing challenges facing our country
in the world but I'm proud to be a part
of that team because these are women who
are supportive of each other
sharing counsel and hosting some very
fun girls dinner's you know women belong
a lot of places where people didn't
always think we belonged when I came to
Harvard Business School in 1975 women
made up only about eleven percent of the
student body but from the moment I
stepped on this campus I felt that I
belonged I think this was actually true
of many of us here today and sometime
during my second year I realized that I
was taking courses mainly focused on
manufacturing it hadn't occurred to me
at the time that this was a
male-dominated industry I came from a
manufacturing family we talked about it
the kitchen table it was in my blood and
I've spent my career buying and
investing in manufacturing businesses
and now helping to develop manufacturing
policy for the country women belong in
manufacturing one of the best parts of
my job as SBA administrators I travel
all around the country every week I'm
meeting small business owners and I met
Rebecca you've keys she's an engineer
and she's president of a manufacturing
company in South Carolina her company
sells electronic components to Boeing
and to the Marines in the Air Force she
is creating good US manufacturing jobs
and she's building capacity in America's
supply chain something HBS is focused on
right professor and I've also had the
pleasure of meeting Sarah Blakely an
entrepreneur and the founder of Spanx we
all love Spanx right
well I won't ask how many are wearing
space I'll just we'll just keep that
Sarah and I recently participated in a
discussion hosted by CNBC and one of the
other panelist was a guy who's it was a
venture capitalist and his underlying
thesis was that when he invest in a
company he wants the management team to
be solely focused on one thing killing
the competition those were his exact
words so Sarah just looked at him and
she said I totally disagree and then she
explained she said when I first cut the
feet out of my pantyhose to make a pair
of white pants look more flattering my
goal was not to kill the competition it
was to create a product that women would
want she was focused on quality creating
value and from that premise she built a
multi-billion dollar brand and created
thousands of jobs so we need more
entrepreneurs like Sarah and Rebecca if
we are going to realize our nation's
full economic potential we need a more
inclusive view of entrepreneurship one
that expands the entrepreneurial playing
field two more women more minorities
more rural and industrial communities
that's how we create jobs that's how we
ensure that America remains globally
competitive doing this comes down to two
factors access and opportunity today
women-owned businesses are one of the
fastest growing segments of new business
in our economy however we know that too
many women entrepreneurs face something
we call the missing middle this has
nothing to do with Spanx
the missing mil refers to the fact that
while women-owned firms are increasing
in number challenges still exist in
scaling their operations today women led
startups are receiving only about six
percent of venture capital dollars in
less than ten percent of the angel
investments however we know that women
make great startup leaders look at women
led private tech companies and drew
mentioned some stats on this this
morning but here's another one according
to research these businesses when
venture-backed bring in twelve percent
higher revenue than their male
counterparts and let me give you an
example for here in Massachusetts women
on thirty-one percent of the businesses
in this state yet they're capturing only
eight percent of the receipts we can see
the same trend across the country
clearly the number of women-owned firms
are growing but they still need to grow
in size and get more access to capital
to compete equally
well that's something I'm proud to say
I've been able to influence during my
time at the SBA for example the SBA has
a hundred billion dollar portfolio of
loan guarantees and research shows that
women and minorities are three to five
times more likely to get an SBA loan
than a conventional bank loan this year
we provided counseling to more than
500,000 women entrepreneurs and small
business owners and across the SBA we
are focused on making sure that more
entrepreneurs of all backgrounds have
the tools that they need to grow their
business to bring new products to market
and to create good jobs now on a
personal note there's a lot of debate
around how women can mean full can
maintain full and balanced professional
and personal lives and I know Cheryl and
many others are going to talk more about
this tomorrow so I don't want to dwell
on it too much but I did want to share
one story you know I often say that what
you learn in the business world is not
really applicable to our roles as wives
and partners and mothers we don't use
360 degree feedback reviews in the mills
household but many of the lessons we
learn as moms can be effective in the
workplace so let me tell you about one
it's called the irrational no
you know where I'm going when i started
in private equity in the 1980s which was
actually before the industry really even
existed i was working on a deal that was
not going particularly well my sons were
young at the time i have three boys and
after a long day of work my evenings
went a little like this can I have
another cookie no can i watch more TV no
can I stay up another hour no so when I
walked into the negotiations the next
day I was sleep deprived and not in a
pleasant mood and rather than my normal
approach which would have been to
compromise and look for common ground I
employed the same tactic that I had used
with my boys so the other side started
making unreasonable demands and I just
said no no no so they were taken aback
they walked out when they returned to
the room they said okay we'll do it your
way
you know I told this story to Ben
Shapiro whom I'm sure many of you will
agree was one of the best professors at
Harvard Business School right so he
asked me when the men learned the
rationale know and I paused and I said I
think they're born knowing it so for
those of you who are thinking about
taking time off or who are currently
taking time off to start and build your
families you should know that when
you're home you're developing and honing
a new set of skills including what one
of my colleagues calls her mom voice
that may prove very valuable in the
workplace now one of the other areas I
want to talk touch upon today is the
question of women and power when I was
at the beginning of my career power was
not something appropriate for women to
want however the times have changed and
for many of us this question has long
been settled we are perfectly
comfortable in positions of power as I
said there are literally hundreds of
reasons why we are uniquely and perhaps
better suited for these positions but
I'll point out too they happen to be the
two Republican senators from my home
state of Maine senator Collins and
former senator Olympia Snowe they are
pragmatists they are solutions focused
they know how to build consensus and get
things done and I would argue that if
there were more senators built in their
mold Washington would be a more
effective and productive town
it's up to each of us to determine where
we want to make our mark and how we want
to use our skills and experiences to
make a difference each of us needs to
make our own choices about the balance
that makes the most sense and how and if
we pursue positions of power but when
it's right for you step up make it
happen and I wanted to tell you a quick
story about what am I make it happen
moments this is from my time in the
public sector which is something i
really encourage all of you to pursue at
some point in your career I promise you
promise you it will be one of the most
rewarding experiences you will ever have
my story starts when I was first
nominated to be SBA administrator it was
december two thousand eight president
obama had just been elected i was flying
to chicago for a press conference in the
drake hotel the president was announcing
my appointment as well as Ron Kirk for
Trade Representative and Ray LaHood for
transportation secretary and Hilda Solis
for labor and they had all been
politicians so while this was a huge day
for all of us they were a little bit
more used to these things we stepped out
onto the stage there were about 50
camera crews the lights were blazing it
was hot I was nervous and I immediately
thought I'm going to pass out
even my husband who was watching on TV
from Maine later said I thought for sure
you were going down so we took our
places behind the president and this is
you've seen this this is what they call
in Washington the potted plant position
right so you stand there for about 20
minutes and when it's your turn you head
to the podium to speak and the president
opened his remarks with a topper now
that's Washington speak for something
new that's added just before the
announcement and today that day it was
about the auto industry now you have to
remember the economy was in shambles at
the time there was a real legitimate
fear that the auto industry would fail
and that the entire economy would
crumble and the president talked about
small businesses and suppliers and
surrounding communities who relied on
the auto industry and I thought to
myself you need to get a grip this is
not about you this is about the jobs and
the livelihood of millions of
hard-working people you know what needs
to be done to help fix this you belong
here this is your time to contribute
you've prepared for this during your
time at Harvard Business School and in
the private sector and it's time to step
up so I stepped up to the podium and I
accepted this enormous responsibility
and I have had the most extraordinary
and challenging experience of my
professional life so my point is it's
okay to have fears but we can't let
those fears hold us back or keep us from
stepping forward or weighing in when the
choice is right for you and you know you
can have an impact step up and always
remember you belong in the room because
this is our campus those are our board
rooms
our negotiating tables and our positions
of leadership it is where we can and
will thrive as I said at the beginning
the mission of the Harvard Business
School is to educate leaders who make a
difference in the world and all of us
here today have accepted the challenge
to open the doors of leadership two more
women because just as inclusive
entrepreneurship is the driving force in
growing our economy inclusive leadership
is what will make our society more
productive more innovative and will lead
us on a path to a more peaceful and a
more prosperous planet thank you
